headline.main: A Presidency Ends: Farewells to Barack Obama
headline.print_headline: A Presidency Ends: Farewells to Obama

docs.snippet: Jobs and inequality should be the issues....
docs.abstract: Jobs and inequality should be the issues.

docs.snippet: As the economic crisis reshaped the presidential race in early October, Senator John McCain abandoned his campaign in Michigan, a state where he had spent $8 million on advertisements and had made repeated appearances.     That decision might have...
docs.lead_paragraph: As the economic crisis reshaped the presidential race in early October, Senator John McCain abandoned his campaign in Michigan, a state where he had spent $8 million on advertisements and had made repeated appearances. That decision might have affected Republican candidates farther down the ticket, as Democrats won close House contests against Republican incumbents, giving Democrats an 8-to-7 edge in the state's delegation. Representative Joe Knollenberg, an eight-term Republican, lost to Gary Peters, a Democrat and former state lottery commissioner, in the Detroit suburbs. Jack Kevorkian, the so-called suicide doctor, won more than 9,000 votes.
docs.abstract: Democrat Gary Peters defeats incumbent Republican Joe Knollenberg in Michigan Congressional election; Democrat Mark Schauer defeats incumbent Republican Tim Walberg; Democratic incumbent Sen Carl Levin retains his seat over wide field of challengers; voters pass ballot initiative to legalize medical marijuana and another to loosen restrictions on stem cell research; Barack Obama wins state, 57-41 percent; tallies (S)

docs.snippet: Why is it his job to confront America’s racism?...
docs.lead_paragraph: Why is it his job to confront America’s racism?
docs.abstract: Bill Keller Op-Ed column contends Pres Obama's approach to issue of race has consistently been calibrated and cautious; suggests people, both black and white, have typecast him according to their own fears and expectations of a black man in the White House; holds this, in effect, is profiling Obama and questions why many believe it is his job to confront America's racism in a more overt way.

Rosenberg, the chief economist and strategist at Gluskin Sheff, noticed some eerie parallels between President Obama's State of the Union speech and some statements by Herbert Hoover, who presided during the early years of the Great Depression. From Mr. Rosenberg's client note today:

docs.snippet: Senator Barack Obama won this swing state, which has seen rapid population growth, demographic shifts and a rapidly deflating real estate market. President Bush won the state in 2004.     Dina Titus, a Democratic state senator and a political scie...
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Barack Obama won this swing state, which has seen rapid population growth, demographic shifts and a rapidly deflating real estate market. President Bush won the state in 2004. Dina Titus, a Democratic state senator and a political science professor at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas, beat the incumbent three-term Republican, Jon Porter, in the Third Congressional District, where Democrats have come to outnumber Republicans since the last election.
docs.abstract: Democrat Dina Titus defeats incumbent Republican Jon Porter in Nevada Congressional race; control of State Legislature shifts to Democrats; Barack Obama wins state, 55-43 percent; tallies (S)
